questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a persistent dry cough and shortness of breath. A CT scan of the chest reveals localized airway obstruction at the level of the terminal bronchioles. Based on Weibel's classification of the respiratory system, which generation of airways is most likely affected in this patient?

choices.text: Generation 4
Generation 8
Generation 16
Generation 20

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Generation 16


Explanation:
Weibel's classification of the respiratory system organizes the airways into 23 generations, starting from the trachea (Generation 0) down to the alveolar sacs (Generation 23).

  • The terminal bronchioles are found at generation/division 16, marking the end of the conducting zone and the beginning of the respiratory zone.
    • This level is critical as it is the last portion of the airways involved in conducting air before gas exchange begins in the respiratory bronchioles.
  • Division number 0 to division number 16 is known as the conducting zone of the airway .
    • Division number 1 to 10 are known as Bronchi. (Option A & B ruled out)
    • Division numbers 11 to 16 are known as terminal bronchioles. (Option C)
  • Division number 17 to division number 23 are responsible for gas exchange and are known as the exchange zone of alveoli. (Option D ruled out)

Substances moving from alveoli to capillary blood can reach equilibrium based on their interactions with blood components during the 0.75 seconds blood spends in the pulmonary capillaries:

  • Nitrous Oxide (Option A):Reaches equilibrium quickly (about 0.1 seconds) as it does not react with blood components. Its uptake is flow-limited because diffusion is not the limiting factor.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with a history of asthma presents with complaints of shortness of breath and wheezing. Pulmonary function tests are performed and indicate that the patient's dynamic compliance is significantly reducd, while static compliance remains relatively unchanged. What is the most likely explanation for these findings?

choices.text: Surfactant deficiency leading to increased alveolar surface tension
Reduced chest wall compliance due to muscle weakness
Increased airway resistance due to bronchospasm
Presence of fibrotic tissue in the lungs, restricting lung expansion

questions.solution:
Answer: C) Increased airway resistance due to bronchospasm

 

Explanation:

Static Compliance:

  • This refers to lung compliance measured when there is no airflow in the lungs. It provides insights into the condition of the lung parenchyma, alveoli, and the chest wall.
  • Surfactant deficiency primarily affects static compliance (Option A)

Dynamic Compliance:

  • This refers to lung compliance measured during continuous airflow, not when breathing is paused. It reflects the additional force needed to overcome airway resistance during breathing.
  • Dynamic compliance considers both airway resistance and the factors influencing static compliance.
  • It is always lower than static compliance due to the added resistance of airflow.
  • Conditions like bronchospasm can reduce dynamic compliance by increasing airway resistance, even when static compliance remains normal.
  • In restrictive lung diseases like fibrosis, both dynamic and static compliance are lower due to increased lung stiffness. (Option D)

Specific Compliance:

  • This measure is calculated by dividing static compliance (C) by the functional residual capacity (FRC).
  • It is particularly useful for comparing lung compliance between individuals of different sizes, as lung size influences overall compliance

Reduced chest wall compliance due to muscle weakness can decrease both static and dynamic compliance. (Option B)

questions.text:
Which of the following denotes the compliance curve depicting both inspiratory and expiratory phase?

(Y-axis denotes volume and x-axis denotes pressure)

choices.text: {{caption_text}}

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D)

 

Explanation: 

HYSTERESIS LOOP:

Inhalation:

  • During inhalation, the inspiratory muscles (primarily the diaphragm) contract, expanding the thoracic cavity. This expansion reduces pleural pressure, creating a more negative pressure compared to the alveolar pressure.
  • The difference between alveolar pressure and pleural pressure, known as transpulmonary pressure, increases, causing the lungs to expand.
  • The inspiratory compliance curve on the compliance diagram illustrates this relationship, showing how lung volume increases as pleural pressure decreases (becomes more negative).
  • The shape of the inspiratory compliance curve is influenced by the elastic properties of the lungs, with steeper curves indicating greater compliance (easier lung expansion).

 

Exhalation:

  • During exhalation, the inspiratory muscles relax, and the elastic recoil of the lungs and chest wall causes the thoracic cavity to decrease in volume. This decrease in volume increases the pleural pressure, making it less negative.
  • As pleural pressure rises, the transpulmonary pressure decreases, leading to lung deflation.
  • The expiratory compliance curve on the compliance diagram depicts this relationship, showing lung volume decreasing as pleural pressure increases (becomes less negative).

questions.text: In the alveoli, surfactant primarily reduces surface tension by:

choices.text: Increasing the viscosity of the alveolar fluid, thereby reducing the tendency to collapse
Interfering with the diffusion of water molecules across the alveolar lining.
Spreading phospholipids and proteins uniformly across the alveolar surface.
Forming a film that alters the behavior of water molecules at the air-liquid interface

questions.solution:
Answer: D) Forming a film that alters the behavior of water molecules at the air-liquid interface

 

Explanation:

Surface tension is a force that arises at the interface of air and liquid, causing the liquid surface to contract.

  • In the lungs, this interface exists between the alveolar fluid and the air inside the alveoli. Surfactant is a surface-active agent in water that significantly reduces the surface tension of water.
  • Surfactant is produced by type II alveolar epithelial cells, which comprise about 10% of the alveolar surface area. Type II alveolar epithelial cells are granular and contain lipid inclusions that are secreted as surfactant into the alveoli.
  • Surfactant is a mixture of phospholipids, proteins, and ions.
  • Dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine, surfactant apoproteins, and calcium ions are the most important components. are primarily responsible for reducing surface tension by partially dissolving in the fluid lining the alveolar surface while the rest spreads over the water's surface in the alveoli.

Importance of Surfactant

  • Surfactant reduces the surface tension in the alveoli, preventing their collapse.
  • The pressure generated by surface tension in an alveolus is inversely proportional to its radius – smaller alveoli experience greater pressure.
  • The absence of surfactant in premature infants with small alveoli can lead to respiratory distress syndrome of the newborn, a potentially fatal condition

Increasing the viscosity of the alveolar fluid, thereby reducing the tendency to collapse (Option A): Surfactant reduces surface tension, but it does not increase viscosity of alveolar fluid.

Interfering with the diffusion of water molecules across the alveolar lining (Option B): Surfactant does not interfere with water diffusion; it acts at the air-liquid interface to reduce surface tension.

Spreading phospholipids and proteins uniformly across the alveolar surface. (Option C): Surfactant is not uniformly spread; it dynamically adjusts its distribution to stabilize alveoli of different sizes.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Old-age lung has high compliance
Elastic tissue recoil and surface tension oppose each other during expansion of alveoli
Hyaline membrane disease has low compliance and high surface tension
Low compliance of the lungs is seen in Atelectasis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Elastic tissue recoil and surface tension oppose each other during expansion

Explanation:

Elastic tissue recoil and surface tension are the two opposing forces to lung compliance and are not opposing forces to each other.

 

Two primary factors influence lung compliance:

  • Elastic forces of the lung tissue:
    • These forces are primarily determined by the presence of elastin and collagen fibers within the lung parenchyma (the functional tissue of the lungs).
    • In a deflated lung, these fibers are contracted and kinked. As the lung expands during inspiration, these fibers stretch and unkink, generating an elastic force that opposes further expansion.
  • Surface tension:
    • A thin layer of fluid lines the inside of the alveoli. At the air-fluid interface within the alveoli, surface tension arises from the stronger attraction between water molecules compared to the attraction between water molecules and air molecules.
    • This surface tension creates an inward pull, attempting to minimize the surface area of the fluid lining the alveoli. Consequently, this inward pull contributes to the elastic recoil of the lungs, making them tend to collapse

 

Option A) Old-age lung has loss of elastic tissue and hence have reduced elastic recoil force, causing easy expansion of lung, i.e high compliance

Option C) Hyaline membrane disease, normally seen in premature babies has low compliance and high surface tension due to reduced production of surfactants.

Option D) Low compliance is seen in atelectasis due to a decrease in lung volume and requires higher pressure to inflate the alveoli.

questions.text: A patient's lung volume increases by 500 ml when their transpulmonary pressure increases from 3 cm H2O to 5.5 cm H2O. What is the compliance of the patient's lungs?

choices.text: 100 ml/cm
150 ml/cm
200 ml/cm
250 ml/cm

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 200 ml/cm

Explanation:

Lung compliance refers to the lungs' ability to stretch and expand in response to changes in transpulmonary pressure.

 

  • Compliance = Change in Lung Volume / Change in Transpulmonary Pressure
  • In this scenario, the change in lung volume is 500 ml, and the change in transpulmonary pressure is 2.5 cm H2O (5.5 cm H2O - 3 cm H2O)
  • Therefore, Compliance = 500 ml / 2.5 cm H2O = 200 ml/cm H2O

questions.text: Two separate patients are being considered for respiratory distress. Imaging reveals an obstruction in the right bronchus in one patient and an embolism in the pulmonary arteriole in another patient. Based on these findings, what are the expected changes in the ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) ratio and the partial pressures of oxygen (PO2) and carbon dioxide (PCO2) in the affected alveoli?

choices.text: In the obstructed bronchus, the V/Q ratio is infinite, and the partial pressures are PO2​​ = 149 mmHg and PCO2​​ = 0.3 mm Hg.
In the embolized vessel, the V/Q ratio is zero, and the partial pressures are PO2​​ = 40 mmHg and PCO2​​ = 46 mm Hg.
In the obstructed bronchus, the V/Q ratio is zero, and the partial pressures are PO2​​ = 40 mmHg and PCO2 = 46 mm Hg.
In the embolized vessel, the V/Q ratio is infinite, and the partial pressures are PO2​​ = 40 mmHg and PCO2​​ = 46 mm Hg.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) In the obstructed bronchus, the V/Q ratio is zero, and the partial pressures are PO2​​ = 40 mmHg and PCO2​​ = 46 mm Hg.

Explanation:
Obstruction:

  • V/Q Ratio: Zero
  • Partial Pressures: The alveoli receive no ventilation, but perfusion continues. Consequently, the partial pressures of gases in the alveoli equilibrate with the venous blood, resulting in PO2​​ = 40 mmHg and PCO2​​ = 46 mmHg. Option (C)  

Embolism:

  • V/Q Ratio: Infinite
  • Partial Pressures: The alveoli receive ventilation, but no perfusion. The partial pressures of gases in the alveoli match those of the inspired air, resulting in PO2​​ = 149 mmHg and PCO2​​ = 0.3 mmHg . 

 

Option (A): V/Q ratio due to obstruction is zero  (not infinity )and the  PO2​​ = 40 mmHg and PCO2​​ = 46 mmHg.

Option (B):V/Q ratio due to embolism is infinite (not zero ) and  PO2​​ = 149 mmHg and PCO2​​ = 0.3 mmHg

Option (D) : In embolism , PO2​​ = 149 mmHg and PCO2​​ = 0.3 mmHg

During the examination, it is noted that his ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) ratio varies significantly in different regions of the lungs. What are the expected partial pressures of oxygen (pO2) and carbon dioxide (pCO2​​) at the apex, middle, and base of the lungs in the upright position?

At the base: pO2​​ is highest and pCO2 is lowest.
At the middle: pO2​​ is highest and pCO2​​ is lowest.
At the base: pO2​​ is lowest and pCO2 is highest.

  • Also, carbon dioxide is very high at the level of basal alveoli because of the huge amount of venous blood and the exit of carbon dioxide into alveoli is incomplete. Therefore, the PCO2 is the highest at the base (PCO2= 42 mm Hg).

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient is evaluated for differences in ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) ratios in various positions. In the upright position, the V/Q ratios at the apex, middle, and base of the lungs differ due to gravitational effects. Which of the following statements correctly describes the V/Q ratio at these lung regions in the upright vs. supine position?

choices.text: In the upright position, the V/Q ratio is highest at the base of the lungs.
In the upright position, the V/Q ratio is highest at the apex of the lungs.
In the supine position, the V/Q ratio difference between the apex and base is more pronounced than in the upright position.
In the supine position, the V/Q ratio is highest at the middle of the lungs.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) In the upright position, the V/Q ratio is highest at the apex of the lungs.

Explanation:

  • Both ventilation (V) and perfusion (Q) are higher at the base than at the apex, in upright position.
  • However, the relative change in blood flow from the apex to the base is greater than the relative change in ventilation, so the ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) ratio is low at the base and high at the apex.
  • In supine position, the apex to base differences in V and Q are negligible.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male patient presents with shortness of breath and fatigue. His respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and his tidal volume is 400 mL. The dead space is estimated to be 150 mL. Which of the following statements about ventilation and perfusion is/are correct?

1) Pulmonary ventilation refers to the amount of air entering the lungs in a minute, while alveolar ventilation is the volume of air reaching the alveolar zone for gas exchange.

2) Pulmonary ventilation for this patient is approximately 6.4L/min.

3) Alveolar ventilation for this patient is approximately 4L/min.

4) Perfusion is the blood flow at the level of the alveoli which is approximately equal to cardiac output from the right ventricle.

choices.text: 1 and 4
1, 2 and 4
1, 3 and 4

questions.solution:
Answer: C) 1, 2, 3 and 4
Explanation:

Statement

Description

Explanation

1) Pulmonary ventilation refers to the amount of air entering the lungs in a minute, while alveolar ventilation is the volume of air reaching the alveolar zone for gas exchange.

Correct

Pulmonary ventilation = TV x RR;

Alveolar ventilation = (TV - Dead Space) x RR.

2) Pulmonary ventilation for this patient is approximately 6.4 L/min.

Correct

Pulmonary ventilation = 400 mL x 16 = 6.4 L/min.

3) Alveolar ventilation for this patient is approximately 4 L/min.

Correct

Alveolar ventilation = (400 mL - 150 mL) x 16 = 4.0 L/min.

4) Perfusion is the blood flow at the level of the alveoli which is approximately equal to cardiac output from the right ventricle.

Correct

Perfusion is typically equal to the cardiac output of the right ventricle, approximately 5.4 L/min.

questions.text: Which statement correctly describes normal inspiration?

choices.text: Diaphragm relaxation leads to decreased intrapleural pressure, allowing air to enter the lungs.
Diaphragm contraction creates negative intrapleural pressure, causing air to enter the lungs.
Increased intra-alveolar pressure from diaphragm contraction draws air into the lungs.
External intercostal muscle relaxation decreases intrapleural pressure, expanding the alveoli.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Diaphragm contraction creates negative intrapleural pressure, causing air to enter the lungs.

Explanation:

Mechanism of Normal Respiration:

Inspiration

  • The diaphragm, which contracts during inspiration and contributes to 75% of the inspiratory effort, and the external intercostal muscles, account for 25% of the inspiratory effort.
  • During normal inspiration, the diaphragm contracts and moves downward.
  • Inspiration results in an increase in intrapleural volume, leading to a decrease in intrapleural pressure from -2.5 mm Hg to -6 mm Hg. This negative intrapleural pressure is the force that expands the alveoli. Greater negative intrapleural pressure causes the alveoli to stretch.
  • As alveolar volume increases, intra-alveolar pressure drops from 0 to -1 mm Hg.
  • This pressure drop below atmospheric levels draws air into the lungs until intra-alveolar pressure reaches equilibrium at 0 mm Hg which marks the end of air entry, concluding inspiration.
  • At the end of inspiration, the alveoli are expanded, and intra-alveolar pressure is 0 mm Hg.

Expiration

  • Expiration is a passive process that occurs when the muscles contracted during inspiration relax.
  • As the diaphragm relaxes, it moves upward, compressing the alveolar space.
  • This compression reduces the volume of the alveoli.
  • As a result, intra-alveolar pressure increases to +1 mmHg, which is higher than atmospheric pressure, pushing air out of the lungs.
  • By the end of expiration, intra-alveolar pressure returns to equilibrium at 0 mmHg.

 

Option A) Diaphragm relaxation would cause an increase in intra-alveolar pressure, not a decrease in intrapleural pressure.

Option C) Diaphragm contraction decreases intra-alveolar pressure (making it negative relative to atmospheric pressure), which allows air to flow into the lungs.

Option D) During normal inspiration, the external intercostal muscles contract, not relax. Their contraction along with diaphragm contraction, helps decrease intrapleural pressure and expand the alveoli.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with severe shortness of breath and chest pain after being involved in a motor vehicle accident. On examination, he is tachycardic and hypotensive, with decreased breath sounds on the right side and tracheal deviation to the left. Which of the following pressure changes most accurately explains the underlying mechanism of his condition?

choices.text: Increased intrapulmonary pressure
Increased intrapleural pressure
Decreased intrapleural pressure
Decreased intrapulmonary pressure

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Increased intrapleural pressure

Explanation:

Based on the provided scenario, the patient most likely has tension pneumothorax, which occurs following a laceration to the lung.

Intrapleural Pressure/Intrathoracic Pressure

  • The intrapleural pressure is typically -2.5 mmHg or -5 cm H₂O, which helps keep the alveoli open.
  • Alveoli tend to collapse unless maintained by a stretching force from inside or negative pressure from outside.
  • Intrapleural fluid is secreted by capillaries in the parietal pleura and absorbed by lymphatics in the visceral pleura. The net force pushing fluid out of capillaries is 9 cm H₂O, and the absorption pressure by lymphatics is 10 cm H₂O. This creates a net negative pressure in the intrapleural space, maintained by lymphatic drainage.
  • The pressure in the alveoli at rest is equal to atmospheric pressure (760 mmHg), and this intra-alveolar pressure is considered 0 mmHg relative to atmospheric pressure.
  • Intrapleural pressure is -2.5 mmHg relative to atmospheric pressure, meaning it is below the atmospheric pressure by 2.5 mmHg.

Changes in Tension Pneumothorax:

  • Some injuries create a one-way valve effect at the site of the damaged visceral pleura.
  • During inspiration, air enters the pleural space, but the valve closes during expiration, trapping the air inside. This repetitive trapping of air with each breath leads to tension pneumothorax.
  • As air continues to accumulate in the pleural space, the intrapleural pressure increases, becoming positive relative to atmospheric pressure (greater than 760 mmHg). This increased pressure compresses the alveoli, which are already prone to collapse.
  • The result is a significant collapse of the lung and a shift of the mediastinum.

 

In contrast, a simple pneumothorax involves air entering the pleural space without the one-way valve effect, leading to a collapse of the lung without the progressive increase in intrapleural pressure or mediastinal shift seen in tension pneumothorax.

 

 

Option A) Increased intrapulmonary pressure generally refers to pressure within the airways and alveoli during conditions like forced expiration or positive-pressure ventilation. This pressure would lead to barotrauma or air trapping.

Option C) Decreased intrapleural pressure does not cause the symptoms observed in tension pneumothorax.

Option D) Tension pneumothorax is characterized by increased intrapleural pressure due to trapped air, not decreased intrapulmonary pressure or fluid accumulation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male holds his breath at the end of normal expiration. Which of the following accurately describes the condition of his lungs at this moment?

choices.text: The alveolar pressure is higher than the atmospheric pressure.
The intrapleural pressure is higher than the atmospheric pressure.
The functional residual capacity is at its minimum.
The elastic recoil forces of the lungs and chest wall are in equilibrium.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) The elastic recoil forces of the lungs and chest wall are in equilibrium.

Explanation:

 

Resting Condition of the Lungs:

  • At the end of a normal exhalation, the lungs are in a state called Functional Residual Capacity (FRC).
  • FRC comprises the Residual Volume (RV) and the Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV). In this state, the respiratory muscles are relaxed.
  • The elastic recoil forces of the lungs, which pull inward, and the chest wall, which pulls outward, are balanced.
  • This equilibrium creates a negative intrapleural pressure, helping to keep the lungs partially inflated and preventing the alveoli from collapsing.

 

At the end of normal expiration, alveolar pressure is equal to atmospheric pressure, not higher. This equilibrium allows the air inside the lungs to stay at rest without any flow in or out. Option A)

The intrapleural pressure is actually lower than the atmospheric pressure. This negative pressure is crucial for keeping the lungs partially inflated and preventing collapse. (Option B)

Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is not at its minimum at the end of normal expiration. FRC is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal exhalation and represents a resting volume where no additional effort is required by the respiratory muscles. (Option C)

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman with a history of asthma presents to the emergency department with severe dyspnea. On examination, she is using accessory muscles to breathe and her oxygen saturation is reduced. Arterial blood gas analysis shows a high level of carbon dioxide (PaCO₂) despite increased ventilation. A bedside pulmonary function test reveals that her physiological dead space has increased compared to her last visit.

Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the increase in physiological dead space in this patient?

choices.text: Increased alveolar dead space due to poorly ventilated but well-perfused alveoli, leading to reduced effective gas exchange.
Anatomical dead space has increased due to an obstruction in the conducting airways, causing less air to reach the alveoli.
Increased alveolar dead space due to poorly perfused but well-ventilated alveoli, reducing the amount of air available for gas exchange.
A reduction in anatomical dead space due to inflammation and narrowing of the airways, leading to a decrease in overall physiological dead space

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Increased alveolar dead space due to poorly perfused but well-ventilated alveoli, reducing the amount of air available for gas exchange.

 

Explanation:

This option best explains the increase in physiological dead space by noting that elevated alveolar dead space (poor perfusion of ventilated alveoli) would lead to ineffective gas exchange, thereby increasing the physiological dead space.

 

Alveolar Dead Space

  • Definition: Alveolar dead space is the portion of the air in the alveoli that is ventilated but not perfused with blood, meaning it does not participate in gas exchange.
  • This occurs when certain alveoli receive air but lack adequate blood flow. Conditions such as pulmonary embolism can cause this imbalance.
  • The presence of alveolar dead space results in inefficient gas exchange, as some of the air that reaches the alveoli cannot be used to oxygenate blood or remove carbon dioxide.

 

Physiological Dead Space

  • Definition: Physiological dead space is the total volume of air in the respiratory system that does not participate in gas exchange. It includes both anatomical and alveolar dead space.
  • Components:
    • Anatomical Dead Space: It is the air in the conducting airways (trachea, bronchi, etc.) where no gas exchange occurs. It is typically about 150 mL in a healthy adult.
    • Alveolar Dead Space: This is the air in alveoli that are ventilated but not perfused.
  • Significance: An increase in physiological dead space means that a greater portion of the inhaled air is not being used effectively for gas exchange. This can result from increases in either anatomical or alveolar dead space.

 

In this case, alveolar dead space would not be increased; instead, the problem would be related to low ventilation-perfusion ratio. The scenario described actually involves increased alveolar dead space due to well-ventilated but poorly perfused alveoli. (Option A)

An increase in anatomical dead space would result from obstructions or increased airway size, not from the alveolar dead space problem described. In this patient, the issue is with the alveoli themselves, not the conducting airways. (Option B)

The patient’s problem is with an increase in physiological dead space, which is primarily due to an increase in alveolar dead space rather than anatomical dead space. Inflammation and narrowing of airways are not consistent with the scenario of increased physiological dead space. (Option D)

questions.text: In the Nitrogen Washout Method for measuring lung volumes, what does the phase III observed in the graph represent?

choices.text: The volume of air in the conducting zone.
The mixed air from the conducting zone and alveoli.
The pure alveolar air coming from the alveolar region.
The closing volume of the lungs.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The pure alveolar air coming from the alveolar region.

 

Explanation:

Nitrogen washout method is used to calculate the volume of anatomical dead space and for measuring the closing volume or closing capacity of the lung.

The procedure of Nitrogen Washout Method:

 

 

 

  • Inhalation Phase:
    • The subject inhales pure oxygen from a cylinder, which replaces the normal atmospheric air in the conducting zone and enters the alveoli.
    • By the end of inhalation, the conducting zone is filled with pure oxygen, while the alveoli have a mix of pure oxygen and residual alveolar air.
  • Expiration Phase:
    • As the subject exhales, the air passing through the nitrogen meter initially contains pure oxygen from the conducting zone, resulting in a zero nitrogen concentration reading.
    • As exhalation progresses, air from the alveolar region—containing a constant nitrogen concentration—begins to mix with the air from the conducting zone.
  • Graph of Nitrogen washout method:
    • The resulting graph of nitrogen concentration versus lung volume will show:
      • An initial zero reading (representing anatomical dead space) (Option A)
      • A gradual increase as alveolar air mixes with the conducting zone air (Option B)
      • A plateau at a fixed nitrogen concentration, which indicates the pure alveolar air (Option C).
      • This is followed by a sudden increase in nitrogen concentration known as the Closing Volume of the Lungs (Option D).

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman undergoes elective surgery under general anesthesia. During the procedure, her respiratory parameters are closely monitored. Which of the following statements best explains how general anesthesia typically affects anatomical dead space?

choices.text: General anesthesia increases alveolar ventilation by reducing dead space.
General anesthesia decreases anatomical dead space by promoting bronchoconstriction.
General anesthesia does not affect anatomical dead space but increases alveolar dead space.
General anesthesia increases anatomical dead space due to the loss of bronchial tone, leading to bronchial dilation.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) General anesthesia increases anatomical dead space due to the loss of bronchial tone, leading to bronchial dilation.

 

Explanation:

Anatomical Dead Space Volume is the volume of air that occupies the conducting zone of the airways and does not participate in the gaseous exchange.

Key Points:

  1. This volume can vary depending on the body weight or the size of the lung of the person.
  2. Measurement: Anatomical dead space volume is calculated as 2.2 multiplied by the body weight (kg) of the person.
  3. Increased volume of this anatomical dead space will be seen in any condition where there is dilation of the conduction zone, or if there is an increased length of this conducting zone.
    • Any kind of bronchodilation experienced by a person will increase the anatomical dead space volume because bronchus and bronchioles will be dilated, which will entrap more dead volume.
    • If general anesthesia is given to a person, there will be a loss of bronchial tone, and dilation will be more, which will be more anatomical dead space. (Option A).
    • In inspiration the length of the anatomical dead space zone is increasing, hence dead space volume will also increase.
    • Extension of the neck and protrusion of the jaw, all done during anesthesia will result in increased anatomical dead space.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of smoking presents with a persistent cough and occasional wheezing. During a physical examination, you notice that the patient has increased breath sounds over the central airways. In which part of the respiratory system is the velocity of airflow is high, leading to turbulent airflow in this patient?

choices.text: Alveoli
Trachea
Terminal bronchioles
Respiratory bronchioles

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Trachea

Explanation:

  • Velocity is inversely proportional to cross-sectional area. In the respiratory system, consider the cross-sectional area of diﬀerent segments like a cross-section of the trachea, both the bronchus and bronchioles, etc,
  • The total cross-sectional area is minimum at division number 3. Hence velocity is highest.

 

  • Velocity will be maximum at division number 3 and then velocity progressively decreases towards the alveoli, and minimum velocity is seen at the level of alveoli.

Alveoli(Option A): The alveoli have the largest total cross-sectional area, leading to minimal airflow velocity and predominantly laminar flow.

Terminal bronchioles(Option C): Terminal bronchioles have a larger cumulative cross-sectional area than the trachea, leading to lower airflow velocity and smoother flow

Respiratory bronchioles (Option D): Respiratory bronchioles, being part of the gas exchange zone, have an even greater cross-sectional area, causing minimal velocity and mostly laminar flow.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of chronic bronchitis presents with increased difficulty in breathing. Based on Poiseuille's law and the distribution of airway resistance, which part of the respiratory system contributes the most to the total resistance to airflow?

choices.text: Alveolar ducts
Small airways (bronchioles)
Medium to large-size bronchi (lobar and segmental bronchi)
Upper airways (pharynx and larynx)

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Medium to large-size bronchi (lobar and segmental bronchi)

Explanation:
The medium to large-size bronchi, specifically the lobar and segmental bronchi, are the site of maximum resistance to airflow. This is because these bronchi have a relatively larger radius but are fewer in number, resulting in higher individual resistance.

  • According to Poiseuille's law, resistance to airflow (R) is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the radius (r) of the airway.
  • Resistance: R = 8ηL/πr4
  • Therefore, small changes in the radius result in significant changes in resistance. Despite the smaller radius of the bronchioles, their parallel arrangement results in a lower total resistance.

The upper airways (pharynx and larynx) also contribute significantly to airflow resistance but less than medium to large-sized bronchi.(Option D)
Only about 20% of the resistance occurs at the level of the small airways. (Option B)
Alveoli have a large cross-sectional area which significantly reduces the resistance according to Poiseuille’s law. Option C)

questions.text: A premature infant presents with severe respiratory distress shortly after birth. The neonate is diagnosed with neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS). Which type of alveolar cell is most likely deficient in this condition, leading to inadequate surfactant production?

choices.text: Type I pneumocytes
Type II pneumocytes
Alveolar macrophages
Endothelial cells

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Type II pneumocytes

Explanation:
Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS) is primarily caused by a deficiency in surfactant, a substance crucial for reducing surface tension in the alveoli and preventing their collapse during exhalation. Surfactant is produced by Type II pneumocytes.

  • Type I pneumocytes (Option A) are thin, flat cells that cover the majority of the alveolar surface and are involved in gas exchange.
  • Alveolar macrophages (Option C) are immune cells that ingest and remove debris and pathogens.
  • Endothelial cells (Option D) line the capillaries surrounding the alveoli and are involved in the exchange of gases between the alveoli and blood.

questions.text: All of the following statements about Clara cells of the respiratory tract are true except:

choices.text: They are found in the bronchioles.
They stabilise surfactant proteins
They have cilia.
They detoxify harmful substances.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) They have cilia.

Explanation:

  • Clara cells, also known as club cells, are non-ciliated, dome-shaped cells found in the bronchioles of the respiratory tract.(Option A ruled out)
  • They play a crucial role in maintaining the integrity of the bronchiolar epithelium by stabilising surfactant proteins that reduce surface tension.(Option B ruled out)
  • They are involved in detoxifying harmful substances through their enzymatic activity.(Option D ruled out)
  • They are not ciliated, differentiating them from other epithelial cells in the respiratory tract that do have cilia, such as the pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelial cells found in the trachea and larger bronchi.

questions.text: A biopsy from a segment of the respiratory tree reveals pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells. From which part of the respiratory tract was this sample most likely taken?

choices.text: Alveoli
Terminal bronchioles
Trachea
Respiratory bronchioles

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Trachea
Explanation:
The epithelial lining of trachea and large bronchi are composed of pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium.

 

 

  • Ciliated epithelium is present at the level of the trachea, bronchus, and bronchioles.
  • Cartilaginous rings are present up to the bronchi.
  • Smooth muscles are present up to respiratory bronchioles (bronchial tone).(Option D ruled out)
  • Epithelial lining
    • Trachea and Large Bronchi: Pseudostratiﬁed columnar ciliated epithelium.
    • Bronchioles: Cuboidal-ciliated epithelium.(Option B ruled out)
    • Alveoli: Simple squamous epithelium.(Option A ruled out)
